oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Territoriality in Birds: Part 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Anderson, Rae V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Territorial boundaries established by birds are sometimes remarkably sharp, even in homogeneous areas such as Horned Lark territories in Grasslands or desert. At certain times territorial boundaries may be relaxed. For example, when some predator attacks one member of a pair the alarm calls of the resident birds will bring neighboring birds into their territory. The neighbors are tolerated until the alarm subsides, then the residents chase the now unwelcome visitors out.
